Issues.Title: Wrong content children order when using ngTemplateOutlet to render
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

Content children should follow dom order but rendering conditionally with ngTemplateOutlet in a different order than ng-template declaration seems to confuse angular. I would expect the order to be based on the resulting DOM and not on the ng-template declaration order.

There should be no difference between:
```html
<app-parent>
  <app-child [order]="1"></app-child>
  <app-child [order]="2"></app-child>
</app-parent>
```
and

```html
<app-parent> <!-- WRONG ORDER -->
  <ng-container *ngTemplateOutlet="one"></ng-container>
  <ng-container *ngTemplateOutlet="two"></ng-container>
  <ng-template #two>
    <app-child [order]="2"></app-child>
  </ng-template>

  </ng-template>
```

Issues.Title: feat(core): change effect() execution timing & no-op `allowSignalWrites`
Issues.Body:
This commit flips the flag that was added in 4e890cc, putting the new effect timing into... effect :)

BREAKING CHANGE:

Generally this PR has two implications:

* effects which are triggered outside of change detection run as part of
  the change detection process instead of as a microtask. Depending on the
  specifics of application/test setup, this can result in them executing
  earlier or later (or requiring additional test steps to trigger; see below
  examples).

* effects which are triggered during change detection (e.g. by input signals) run _earlier_, before the component's template.

We've seen a few common failure cases:

* Tests which used to rely on the `Promise` timing of effects now need to `await whenStable()` or call `.detectChanges()` in order for effects to run.

* Tests which use faked clocks may need to fast-forward/flush the clock to cause effects to run.

* `effect()`s triggered during CD could rely on the application being fully rendered (for example, they could easily read computed styles, etc). With the change, they run before the component's updates and can get incorrect answers. The recent `afterRenderEffect()` API is a natural replacement for this style of effect.

* `effect()`s which synchronize with the forms system are particularly timing-sensitive and might need to adjust their initialization timing.

Fixes #55311
Fixes #55808
Fixes #55644
Fixes #56863

Issues.Title: fix(zone.js): remove `abort` listener once fetch is settled
Issues.Body: This commit updates the `fetch` patch for zone.js. Currently, we're attaching an `abort` event listener on the signal (when it's provided) and never removing it. Issues.Title: viewChild.required() is lying about its type - please remove this API while it's still in developer preview!
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

I was both shocked and amused about how `viewChild.required()` handles the case when it's accessed too early.

An exception is thrown, pointing to https://angular.dev/errors/NG0951

While that's better than nothing, I still have to ask: why does `viewChild.required()` lie about its type? It's nice to try to guarantee that it can't be null (or undefined). But in fact, you just can't guarantee that: **so please remove `viewChild.required()`** as it tricks developers into falsely thinking that the ViewChild is there and accessible while in fact it's not (and it can't be guaranteed). There's still time to do so because `viewChild.required()` is still in developer preview!

After all, the TypeScript type should reflect the reality and not something along the lines "it's not correct now, but will be in the future when the necessary lifecycle has finished". 

So please: consider removing `viewChild.required()`. It's much better to be honest about the type and let the developers use optional chaining. Because of the Signal based nature I suppose everybody can live with an initial `null` (or `undefined`) value and wait a little bit until the viewChild arrives. Especially because this is how `@ViewChild()` works and everybody was fine with it. It's far better to expect the `undefined` (or `null` value) than to spam NG0951 exceptions into the application.

Issues.Title: fix(http): cleanup JSONP script listeners once loading completed
Issues.Body:
This commit removes event listeners from the `script` element once loading is
complete. If the element is not garbage collected properly, in Firefox, the script
element still appears in the memory tree view, captured by
`__zone_symbol__loadfalse -> HTMLScriptElement -> GC Roots`. We should always be good
citizens and clean up event listeners when we no longer need them, as browser's garbage

Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

compiler-cli, compiler

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

I would appreciate an explanation of the situation.

If it works as expected, please explain why that is the case?
If there is a problem, please pay attention to it!

In some cases of writing text in tags, after compilation, spaces are added at the beginning and end of the text, which were not there initially.

Issues.Title: Building out-of-module TypeScript code
Issues.Body:
### Command

build, serve

### Description

I am migrating a suite of AngularJS applications to Angular.    All of the existing JS code is currently in the main `public` assets folder so is copied verbatim into the `dist` folder.   All of the code is ESM format .mjs files.

Much of the code is generic JS  and not components, etc.   I wish to gradually rewrite these into TypeScript, so that they can be imported by both the existing code and new Angular components with full type checking and intellisense.

This implies a transpiling step, and I would dearly love for this to be automated via the `watch` system so that `ng serve` notices changes and automatically reloads the code on edit.    While a `tsc && ng build` process might work, it would be very tedious to have to manually rebuild after every edit.

### Describe the solution you'd like

I had hoped that the `scripts` setting would work, but alas no.  (I have seen #17125 and #6393)

I need either individual `.(m)js` files to be generated from the TypeScript, or for specific files to end up in particular bundles.  Since importing a typical AngularJS module has implicit side effects the four separate apps can't all end up in one bundle.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Description

When you run `ng serve` in 19.0.0-next.2, and then open http://localhost:4200/bar/foo in the browser, you will get an error in the console:

```
11:21:13 AM [vite] Pre-transform error: Failed to load url /bar/main.js (resolved id: /bar/main.js). Does the file exist?
```

If you close the browser window, restart the dev server, and load http://localhost:4200/bar or http://localhost:4200/ in the browser, there is no error in the console.

This behavior seems to appear in 19.0.0-next-2 to 19.0.0-next-5, and doesn't happen in 19.0.0-next-1.

```typescript
];
```

Issues.Title: perf(@angular/cli): enable Node.js compile code cache when available
Issues.Body:
The Angular CLI will now enable the Node.js compile cache when available for use. Node.js v22.8 and higher currently provide support for this feature. The compile cache stores the v8 intermediate forms of JavaScript code for the Angular CLI itself. This provides a speed up to initialization on subsequent uses the Angular CLI. The Node.js cache is stored in a temporary directory in a globally accessible location so that all Node.js instances of a compatible version can share the cache. The code cache can be disabled if preferred via `NODE_DISABLE_COMPILE_CACHE=1`.

Based on initial profiling, this change provides an ~6% production build time improvement for a newly generated project once the cache is available.

```
Benchmark 1: NODE_DISABLE_COMPILE_CACHE=1 node ./node_modules/.bin/ng build
  Time (mean ± σ):      2.617 s ±  0.016 s    [User: 3.795 s, System: 1.284 s]
  Range (min … max):    2.597 s …  2.640 s    10 runs

Benchmark 2: node ./node_modules/.bin/ng build
  Time (mean ± σ):      2.475 s ±  0.017 s    [User: 3.555 s, System: 1.354 s]
  Range (min … max):    2.454 s …  2.510 s    10 runs

Summary
  node ./node_modules/.bin/ng build ran
    1.06 ± 0.01 times faster than NODE_DISABLE_COMPILE_CACHE=1 node ./node_modules/.bin/ng build
```

Issues.Title: bug(form_field): Autofill pseudo-selector is not dark mode responsive
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

`mat-form-field` has the ability to apply the `:autofill` pseudo-selector, which Chrome's current user agent stylesheet has 
```
input:internal-autofill-selected {
    appearance: menulist-button;
    background-image: none !important;
    background-color: light-dark(rgb(232, 240, 254), rgba(70, 90, 126, 0.4)) !important;
    color: fieldtext !important;
}
```

The infrastructure to support light and dark contexts in GM2/GM3 do not assign `color-scheme: light/dark`, which causes these [system-colors](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/system-color) to be unresponsive to the currently selected color-context. 

I'm not entirely sure at which point a framework is capable of over-riding user agent stylesheets, but the framework should be accepting and work with these new settings when the infrastructure already has controls to choose between these contexts to have a less breaking experience.

### Reproduction

Material demo:  https://material.angular.io/components/form-field/overview#form-field-overview
1. Select either of the dark themes on the page (I chose magenta and violet)
2. Enter text into any of the form fields
3. Force the :autofill pseudo selector to be enabled via dev-console



### Expected Behavior

I would expect to see lighter colored font and a darker background-color

This can be achieved by following the above example and then
4. assign `color-scheme: dark` to any parent to the <input> element.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/089574f8-5ba3-4dd0-a5e4-eb17b2db5593)


### Actual Behavior

5. Note that the color and background-color of the input field have been changed to [system-color](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/system-color):` fieldtext` and `background-color:light-dark(hex,hex)`
6. The colors are non-compatible with dark theme contexts

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f2a768cd-141b-4bc9-a739-a38c6b030cb3)

### Environment

- Angular: 18
- CDK/Material: 18.2.4
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS

Issues.Title: bug(table): Performance issue when paginator is set on AfterViewInit
Issues.Body: ### Is this a regression? - [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version ### The previous version in which this bug was not present was _No response_ ### Description According to [documentation](https://material.angular.io/components/table/overview#table-pagination) the recommended way of setting up a table with paginator is by doing this: ``` @ViewChild(MatPaginator) paginator: MatPaginator; dataSource: MatTableDataSource; ngOnInit(): void { this.dataSource.data = this.getMillionsOfRows(); } ngAfterViewInit() { this.dataSource.paginator = this.paginator; } ``` But because no paginator is defined until view is initialized, the whole table will be rendered the first time which can cause a significant performance issue. In my case real-case project, I'm experiencing ~750ms to render 600 elements in a 8 columns table, and ~80 ms with workaround n°2. ### Workarounds 1. Use `@ViewChild(MatPaginator, { static: true }) paginator: MatPaginator;` and set paginator to dataSource on init. => Does not work if paginator is in a conditional block (`@if` for example) 2. or, Set data to dataSource after view init. => Not great, the table will be rendered empty at first. ### Reproduction Stackblitz link: https://material.angular.io/components/table/examples#table-overview Steps to reproduce: 1. Open Material example in Stackblitz 2. Edit table-overview-example.ts and add the following method to the component: ``` test() { console.log('test'); } ``` 3. Edit table-overview-example.html and change the first `` tag to: ``` {{ test() }} {{row.id}} ``` 4. Open browser the console and refresh the view ### Expected Behavior 5 logs, i.e. the page size. ### Actual Behavior 100 logs, i.e. the total number of elements. ### Environment - Angular: >18 - CDK/Material: >18 - Browser(s): Chrome - Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(table): Performance issue when paginator is set on AfterViewInit" (#29759)
